title: Xi's shockwaves and TSMC's delicate position
text:
Hello everyone. This is Cissy from Hong Kong. It's been a tough week for investors and multinational companies unnerved by developments in China.

It has been fraught for China's tech workers, too. On Monday night, as the US shares of many Chinese companies were in free fall, I received a flurry of messages from friends working at China's leading tech companies telling me how desperate they were to leave the country.

The messages and the share sell-off were both sparked by President Xi Jinping cementing his control of the Chinese Communist party the previous day with a historic third term and a top leadership packed with loyalists.

But this move should not have come as such a surprise. Rumours that Xi was planning to rule for life were already circulating in 2016, two years before Beijing formally abolished presidential term limits. Back then, too, I remember hearing people say they would leave China — though few followed through on those plans.

Still, it is shocking how quickly things have changed since last year, when Xi began a sweeping overhaul of the country's tech sector. Businesses that once attracted workers with lavish pay came under pressure to cut costs, and the resulting lay-offs and share price plunges left many employees struggling to pay their mortgages.

Black Monday 2.0

Fears over the direction of Asia's biggest economy under a freshly empowered Xi sparked a historic sell-off of China tech stocks on Monday, spreading from Hong Kong to New York and sending the Hang Seng Tech Index down over 9 per cent and the Nasdaq Golden Dragon China Index down as much as 20 per cent, Nikkei Asia's Echo Wong and Cissy Zhou write. Shares in Alibaba Group Holding at one point fell below the $68 price of its mega IPO in 2014.

While markets bounced back a bit over the next two days, doubts are lingering over how investible the Chinese tech sector will be following the outcome of the party congress. Fears are mounting that Xi's hardline approach toward the sector may continue, while his iron grip on power means few if any will be in a position to challenge his policy decisions. Restoring market confidence at this stage, analysts say, will be “extremely hard.”

These uncertainties come among other headwinds. The yuan recently weakened to a 14-year low against the dollar, and there are fears that China will stick to its stringent zero-Covid policy. Some had hoped the end of the party congress, the most important political event of the year, would usher in a softening of pandemic measures. But fresh lockdowns have been reported in a number of Chinese cities this week, affecting areas that collectively account for at least 8.5 per cent of China's GDP.

The TSMC question

Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co dominates the global supply of semiconductors but, as tensions between Washington and Beijing grow, the US is becoming increasingly worried about its reliance on the contract chipmaker, report the Financial Times' Kathrin Hille and Demetri Sevastopulo.

TSMC makes semiconductors for a host of international companies, including tech giant Apple and chip company AMD. A huge 92 per cent of the world's advanced chips are now made in Taiwan.

If the world were to lose access to Taiwanese chip manufacturing, production of everything from cars to mobile phones would be severely disrupted. Taiwan's leaders hope this dominance in the chip industry gives the island a “silicon shield,” a guarantee that the US would come to the rescue if China were to attack.

But the US's strategic goals and its fears of China are leading Washington to reconsider its reliance on TSMC. In addition to trying to cut Beijing off from supplies of key advanced semiconductors, Washington is also attempting to reduce its own dependency on Taiwan for chip supplies, with Joe Biden's administration passing legislation to develop US-based semiconductor manufacturing.

Experts warn the US will need to invest much more in chipmaking than it currently has planned if it is to rival Taiwan. But for TSMC, the future is already looking fraught, as Chinese sabre-rattling and US protectionism point to years of challenges ahead.

A decade of tech and tensions

China has produced some of the world's biggest and most successful tech companies over the past decade, including Alibaba, Tencent, Baidu, ByteDance — and Huawei Technologies.

Huawei once ranked among the world's largest smartphone manufacturers. But as tech tensions between Washington and Beijing grew under then US President Donald Trump, the Chinese tech champion was put on a US blacklist and cut off from its most important suppliers. Today, Huawei hardly ranks in the top 10 smartphone brands globally.

In many ways, Huawei's trajectory epitomises Chinese tech under a decade of Xi Jinping. The country's technology manufacturing abilities have grown exponentially, and its suppliers are deeply entwined in global supply chains. But even the mightiest of these companies must contend with internal and external political forces beyond their control.

Caught in the middle

South Korean chipmakers Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix have received a 12-month reprieve from US export controls aimed at China's chip sector, but they are not breathing a sigh of a relief, write Nikkei Asia's Kim Jaewon and Cheng Ting-Fang.

Samsung and SK Hynix both have massive production footprints in China, churning out different types of memory chips for electronic devices. The country accounts for more than 40 per cent of the in-house Nand flash memory chips produced by Samsung, the world's largest maker of such chips, and about 40 per cent of the DRam chips made by SK Hynix.

While the waiver allows the two to keep using American chip technology at their China plants for 12 months, what happens after that is anyone's guess. This uncertainty, sources say, has spurred the companies to start coming up with back-up plans to keep production on track.

SK Hynix in its earnings call this week spelt out in bold terms what such plans entail. “As a contingency plan, we are considering selling the fab [production facility], selling the equipment or transferring the equipment to South Korea,” chief marketing officer Kevin Noh said on Wednesday.
